update.title: Improve sensor update rate

content.raw:
I just ran this script with a slightly patched version of gztopic.


```
#!c++
#!/bin/bash

TIME=10

avg()
{
	INPUT_FILE=$1
	OUTPUT_FILE=$2

	count=0;
	total=0;

	for i in $( awk '{ print $1; }' $INPUT_FILE )
	   do
	     total=$(echo $total+$i | bc )
	     ((count++))
	   done
	echo "scale=2; $total / $count" | bc > $OUTPUT_FILE
}

for I in {1..6}
do
	TOPIC=/gazebo/default/multicamera_$I/link/cam$I/images
	echo $TOPIC

	# Run gztopic hz on each camera to collect the stats.
	timeout $TIME gztopic hz $TOPIC > log$I

	# Get the average of every topic
	avg log$I log$I\_avg
done
```

I run the script with gazebo running from this branch and from default (using the world file of this pull request). Those are the results:


```
#!c++
       Expected        default   ThisPR
cam1      10            9.82       9.81
cam2      20           19.64      19.67
cam3      30           25.05      24.90
cam4      40           29.03      29.72
cam5      50           26.02      28.29
cam6      60           22.99      25.51
```
It looks that we do it better in the topics where we do not reach the limit. Is that the expected result? 

It looks good to me.
content.html:
I just ran this script with a slightly patched version of gztopic.

#!/bin/bash

TIME=10

avg()
{
    INPUT_FILE=$1
    OUTPUT_FILE=$2

    count=0;
    total=0;

    for i in $( awk '{ print $1; }' $INPUT_FILE )
       do
         total=$(echo $total+$i | bc )
         ((count++))
       done
    echo "scale=2; $total / $count" | bc > $OUTPUT_FILE
}

for I in {1..6}
do
    TOPIC=/gazebo/default/multicamera_$I/link/cam$I/images
    echo $TOPIC

    # Run gztopic hz on each camera to collect the stats.
    timeout $TIME gztopic hz $TOPIC > log$I

    # Get the average of every topic
    avg log$I log$I\_avg
done

I run the script with gazebo running from this branch and from default (using the world file of this pull request). Those are the results:

       Expected        default   ThisPR
cam1      10            9.82       9.81
cam2      20           19.64      19.67
cam3      30           25.05      24.90
cam4      40           29.03      29.72
cam5      50           26.02      28.29
cam6      60           22.99      25.51

It looks that we do it better in the topics where we do not reach the limit. Is that the expected result?

It looks good to me.

content.raw: Thanks. I'll switch them all to the new approach.

content.raw: Tests in `vrc_task_1`  on my machine show some increase in Hz when all seven gpu sensors are running, from 14Hz to 17Hz
content.html: Tests in vrc_task_1 on my machine show some increase in Hz when all seven gpu sensors are running, from 14Hz to 17Hz
jenkins report, all tests pass

content.raw:
So now there're 2 different approaches to updating gpu sensors:

1. `GpuRaySensor` and `MultiCameraSensor` use `event::Events::ConnectRender` (new approach), 
2. `CameraSensor` and `DepthSensor` keep the same `Render()` then `PostRender()` sequence.

I wonder if we should switch them all to the new approach so it's consistent between the sensors, or have a way to specify the update approach to use?
content.html:
So now there're 2 different approaches to updating gpu sensors:

  1. GpuRaySensor and MultiCameraSensor use event::Events::ConnectRender (new approach),
  2. CameraSensor and DepthSensor keep the same Render() then PostRender() sequence.

I wonder if we should switch them all to the new approach so it's consistent between the sensors, or have a way to specify the update approach to use?

content.raw: I remember the sensors were not giving out the right Hz. Other than that we'll need to verify that the timestamps are also correct.
content.html: I remember the sensors were not giving out the right Hz. Other than that we'll need to verify that the timestamps are also correct.
